title: 114_s1600
content: The Act titled "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Exclusive remedies under this section are limited to designated Federal agencies or components. The Privacy Act extends remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional disclosures. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" with the concurrence of other officials. The Privacy Act allows for information sharing with foreign countries or organizations that have appropriate privacy protections in place for preventing, investigating, detecting, or prosecuting criminal offenses. The Attorney General, in consultation with other key departments, can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with information sharing agreements, no longer meets requirements, or hinders the transfer of information to the United States for reporting or preventing unlawful activity. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies or components for information sharing purposes, requiring concurrence from relevant agency heads. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies or components for information sharing purposes, with determinations published in the Federal Register and not subject to review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over claims arising under this section.
